title: Graph on Arrival of Enslaved Africans - patterns

content.description:
New Arrivals of Enslaved Africans into Four Major Regions of the North American Mainland, Before and After 1750

For each data category, the following bars are shown:
1619–1750
1751–1860
All values are approximate.
The Enslaved Africans Arriving data for the 4 categories are as follows:
Northern United States:
1619–1750: 21,000
1751–1860: 18,000
Chesapeake:
1619–1750: 101,000
1751–1860: 38,000
Carolinas/Georgia:
1619–1750: 48,000
1751–1860: 176,000
Gulf States:
1619–1750: 10,000
1751–1860: 20,000
content.question: Which of the following helps to explain the large numbers of enslaved Africans arriving in the Carolinas and Georgia, as shown in the graph?

choices.label: The Carolinas and Georgia received many who had escaped their enslavement in Spanish Florida.
Charleston, South Carolina became the center of the United States slave trade.
The large number of enslaved Africans in Georgia and the Carolinas made it easier for them to blend into existing African American communities.
Approximately half of the enslaved Africans who arrived in North American ports came from Christian or Muslim societies in Africa.

content.answer: Charleston, South Carolina became the center of the United States slave trade.
